div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.
Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passenegers to the ship.

The Brindial Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passenegrs can go on board the evening before. The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arrivnig in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is €22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
the Sea fares are:
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passenegers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
div.head: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
div.head: RED SEA LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 11.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1905
div.p: AN ANGLO-RUSSIAN ENTENTE

Our London Correspondent informs us by telegram that negotiations are about to be opened with a view to the conclusion of an Anglo-Russian understanding, aiming at the maintenance of the status quo in Asia, and the restoration of Russia to her old and true position as a European Power. The return of Count de Benckendorff to St. Petersburg and of Sir Charles Hardinge to London, is interpreted as a sign that definite suggestions as to the extent and nature of this agreement have been put forward by the Governments involved, and are being communicated to their respective ambassadors. It remains to be seen whether the conclusion of any such agree- ment is in reality fessible. Nothing is im- possible in diplomacy. We have seen France and England, at one time bitterly hostile, become firm friends. The relations between Germany and Austria led to an alliance within a few years of the war of 1866, and to go back to the early years of the nine- teenth century England, after being repeat- edly at war with Spain, became the ally of her erstwhile enemy against the armies of Napoleon. But in the present case there are certain reasons, as much of a geographical as of a political nature, that must throw consider- able difficulties in the way of any permanent arrangement with the Russian Empire.

A mutual agreement to respect the status quo in Asia is of excellent augury for the im- mediate future of the British and Russian Asiatic Empires, but, in the nature of things, it is un- likely to be permanent, if Russia is to find no outlet on the open sea in Europe. Russia's whole foreign policy aims at reaching the open water : an Anglo-Russian agreement concern- ing Asia leaves two courses open to the Rus- sian Government. It may "mark time", till its strength has been restored, or it may make its influence felt once more in the Bulkans, with

div.head: Sunlight
div.p: There is no rubbing and scrubbing with
Sunlight Soap
One bar of it, when used according to directions, will do more than two bars of common soap.
Soap

the object of reaching Constantinople or Alex- andretts, its only outlet now that the Persian Gulf and the Far Eastern seas are guarded by the Anglo-Japanese forces. It is to be presumed that the understanding, of which our Correspondent speaks contemplates the first of these two alternatives, for we cannot imagine any British stateman aiding Russia to reach the Mediterranean at the expense of Austria or even of Turkey, which is, after all, the leading Moslem Power. An Anglo-Russian understanding, then, must be of a purely pacific character, and will in substance be nothing more than an affirmation, on the part of Russia, of the Anglo-Japanese Treaty. It is to be regretted that in the present state of popular feeling on both sides of the North Sea, such an understanding may be regarded as an attempt to isolate the German Empire. We cannot believe that any such meaning is to be attached to an essentially pacific agreement, but it is very possible that the German Foreign Office may be rendered somewhat uneasy by the idea. It would be a strange consequence of the proposed under- standing if it hastened the formation of a great central European league, for the Austro- Hungarian conflict is quite likely to subside the instant that Russian influence once more makes itself felt in the Balkans; Roumania may well be forced to ally herself yet more closely with Germany and Austria from a fear of the Slava. and the Sultan may see in friend- ship with such a league his only guarantee for the future against the might of Russia.

div.head: THE TSAR AND HIS PEOPLE
div.p: The Imperial manifesto issued last week at St. Petersburg (says the "Globe") is quite a model of frankness, and so far as that merit goes, it deserves the warmest appreciation. Candid admission is made at the very begin- ing that the Russian Empire has suffered "sore trials and blows of Fate in a sanguinary war," and Japan is lauded as "a brave and mighty enemy." Hopes are further expressed that Russia and her late foe will, for the future, live in peace and neighbourliness in Eastern Asia, heartily co-operating in the develop- ment of that very backward region. As the Mikado had previously expressed that aspir- ation, the present Imperial utterance may be considered in the light of a hand-shake. But even of greater consquence is the passage in which the Tsar pledges himself to convene some sort of a Parliment to help him in the gigantic and ever-growing labour of promoting the welfare and prosperity of his subjects. There is no reserva- tion whatever ; the undertaking, if carried out, cannot fail to impair, if not to destroy, the Autocracy. But the Bureaucracy and other privileged classes have shown, again and again, as much adroitness as unscrpulousness in covertly setting at nought the expressed desires of their Monarch. For the moment, the Tsar commands the situation, but the fell shadow behind the Throne is not in the least obliterated or even attenuated. Judging from past experiences, elaborate pretences will be made of loyal obedience to the Imperial Com- mand, but unless the Tsar shows more master- fulness than on previous occasions of the sort, it is a safe prophecy that he will again be as clay in the hands of the potter. He has unhappily gravitated to the position of a really powerless despot, who is made the scapegoat when things go wrong.

div.head: RUSSIAN UNREST
CAPITAL CUT OFF.
ALARMING SITUATION.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, October 25.

Eight, thousand railway men have met here and decided on a general strike to-day on all the railways serving St. Petersburg. The men of the Vistula railroads struck at midnight The railway strike at Moscow is spreading in every direction, involving a dozen of the prin cipal towns.

The railway men have sent a deputation to M. Witte, declaring that the only remedy for the present situation is political liberty, and the convocation of a National Assembly elect- ed by direct universal suffrage. Enough blood has already been shed in Manchuria and in the cities of Russia. (Reuter)
LODZ, October 25.
Thirty thousand workmen in the factories struck yesterday. The strike is political in character. The proclamation of martial law is imminent.(reuter)
Moscow, October 26.
The Congress of Social Democrats has de- cided to form local clubs and committees throughout the Empire for the purpose of taking united action. (Reuter)
St. Petersburg, October 25.

The city is completely cut off, except by telegraph. Sir C. Hardinge has been unable to leave. The gravity of the situation is hourly asserting itself. The whole state of the muni- cipal organisations is dislocated by ramifica- tions of the strike movement, which, it is believed, owes its origin, to a great extent, to the intensity of the discontent at the inade- quacy of the proposed reforms.

M. Witte, replying to the deputation of railway employes, admitted the justice of some of their demands, while others were absolutely unrealisable ; such, for example, as that of universal suffrage, which is inspired by outside influences. He promised the liberty of the press and meeting. The deputation was disap- pointed. A meeting of the railway employes and students was subsequently held at the University. Revolutionary speeches were deli- vered.
Rioting and looting are reported from Riga. There are many killed and wounded. (Reuter)

St. Petersburg, October 25. The hands at the Putiloff and other great works have struck. The troops at Ekaterinoslav fired a volley into an assemblage of railway employes to-day, and also into a political demonstration. There are a number of killed and wounded. (Reuter)
St. Petersburg, October 25. All railway communication has been cut off. Several factories have gone on strike. Food is becoming dear. The circulation of trains has also stopped at Warsaw. (Havas)

div.head: MACEDONIA.
ACTION OF THE POWERS.
div.p: London, October 25.

Reutor’s Agency learns that the next stop in the financial control of Macedonia will be that the Russian and Austro-Hungarian Am- bassadors will be received by the Sultan. The adoption of coercive measures largely depends on the result of this audience. It is not true that Germany is not acting in accord with the other Powers, though whether all would participate in an eventual naval demonstra- tion is immaterial, as their unity is un- doubted. The Russian Black Sea fleet has sailed from Odessa fi r the Anatolian coast to-day. It is believed that this is in connection with such a demonstration. (Reuter)

div.head: KING AND QUEEN OF-GREECE.
VISIT TO ENGLAND.
div.p: London, October 25.
Their Majesties the King and Queen of Greece will arrive at Windsor on the 13th November. They will be accompanied by Prince and Princess Nicholas. A reception will be held at the Guildhall. (Rueter)

div.head: ORDER RESTORED IN SANTIAGO.
div.p: Santiago (Chili), October 25. 3,000 troops have arrived here and order is restored. (Reuter)

div.head: GENOA HARBOUR EXTENSION.
div.p: GENOA October 25.
The French Squadron have arrived to attend the inauguration of the harbour extension by the King and Queen. (Reuter)
NORWAY AND PRINCE CHARLES.
Christiania, October 25.

The Government has asked the Storthing for authority to enter into negotiations with Prince Charles of Denmark with a view to his accepting the crown, provided that the choice be approved by a plebiscite. (Reuter)

div.head: ENGLAND AND RUSSIA
A RAPPROCHEMENT.
NEGOTIATIONS PROGRESSING
(Gazette’s Special Service.)
div.p: London, Wednesday Oct. 25.

The statement published in the home press to the effect that the negotiations between Russia and Germany have resulted in a rap- prochoment is untrue ; but it is quite correct that the negotiations now in progress both in London and St. Petersburg are about to assume definite shape. Sir Charles Hardinge’s return to London and Count de Benckondorff’s return to St. Petersburg are connected with the pour- parlors which are necessary before a complete understanding can be reached, and which it is probable will have as its object an entente on the maintenance of the status quo and the development of commercial interest in Asia, together with the resumption by Russia of be former role as a European Power.
London, October 25.
The "Times" learns from St. Petersburg that tho visit of Sir C. Hardinge to London is believed to be connected with pourparlers for an Anglo-Russian rapprochement (Reuter)

div.head: ROYAL VISIT TO JAPAN.
div.p: London, October 25.
Prince Arthur of Connaught will start for Japan early in 1906. (Reuter)

div.head: EMBASSY FOR TOKIO.
div.p: London, October 25.
It is authoritatively announced that the King has decided that the Location at Tokio shall be immediately raised to an Embassy. (Reuter)

div.head: MOROCCO CONFERENCE.
div.p: Tangier, October 25.
The Sultan has agreed to the programme of the Algeciras Conference. (Havas)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: CHRYSANTHEMUM SHOW- THE K. H. S an- nnual Chrysanthemum Show will take place at Ghezireh on the 4th and 5th of November. STRAY DOGS.- Stray and ownerless dogs found int he Shoubra district of Cairo during the night of Friday will be poisoned by the police.
VISIT OF JAPANESE FLEET.- There is a rumour current to the effect that a Japanese fleet, under the command of Admiral Togo, will shortly visit the principal Mediterranean port, including Alexandria.

“LA FETE DU NIL.”- Maestro Giodano has commenced the score of a new opera, of which M. Victorien Sardon has written the book specifically for him. The opera is called “La Fete Du Nil,” and the action takes place in Egypt at the time of Napoleon.

AMATEUR THEATRICALS.- The Ernesto Rossi Dramatic Club are giving a performance at the Eden Theatre on Sunday evening next of Bisson’s popular comedy Il Controllere dei Vagoni-Letti. The curtain will rise at 9.15 on a one-act drama entitled L’Amico.

EXECUTIONS.- Mahrons Mustapha Suleiman, of Tendeh, Mellawi Markaz, who was sen- tenced to death for the murder of Mustapha Abdel Ghani on February 5, and Ramadan Hassan, of Assiot, also sentenced to death for the murder of Makar Abdel Malak on March 11, are to be executed on the 31st inst. and the 1st proxo, respectively, within the prison of the Cairo Gouvernorat.

UNHAPPY EMPLOYES.- The employes of the Mehkemeh Sharieh have published in the columns of the native Press the text of a petition which they recently submitted to the Grand Cadi of Egypt pointing out that their salaries are so small that they hardly suffice to supply them with the bare necessities of existence. In their petition the clerks say that while everything in Egypt has changed for the better, the State revenues grow greater and greater, and the salaries of all the officials and employes of the Government have been increased, the unlucky employes of the Mehkemeh Sharieh alone find no improvement in their condition.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d’Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 P.M
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
<DEPARTURE FROM ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: At 7.30 a.m. to-day H.H. the Khedive’s train steamed out of Moharrem Bey station to the accompaniment of the salutes fired by the Kom el Dik guns.

The station was crowded at an early hour by holders of special invitations to witness the departure of his Highness for Cairo. Among those present were Mahoud Sidky Pasha, Governor of Alexandria, Adniral Sir R. M. Blomfield, Chitty Bey, Cobbe Bey and other important officials, theulema and the heads of the various religious communities, and a great number of native European notables. The Streets had been decorated and were thronged with sightseers, and a strong con- tingent of boy musicians form the Moslem charitable schools was drawn up in Cherif Pasha-street. They played the Khedivial hymn and uttered the Turkish salute of “Efendimiz chok yashs,” as the Khedive drove up to the station in the company of H.H Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan, escorted by well-mounted trospers and followed by carriages containing the Ministers (of whom T.E. Boutros Pasha Ghali and Hussein Pasha Fakry came up from Cairo yesterday) and the principal officials of the Maieh Sanieh.

On the arrival of the Khedivial carriage at the station of Governor of Alexandria and the commander of the British forces at Alex- andria, with a number of native European notables, met the Khedive, while the guard of honor, composed of three officers and a hundred men of the 3rd Battalion and a detachment of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, presented arms, and the bands played the Khedivial salute.

After bidding a hearty farewell to many of those present to see him off, H.H. the Khedive entered the train, followed by the Ministers and his s ute, and at 7.30 a.m. the thunder of guns from Fort Kom el Dik proclaimed the news of the Khedives departure for the Capital.

div.head: ARRIVAL AT CAIRO
div.p: Long before H.H. the Khedive’s train was due to arrive in Cairo, small knots of people began to collect in and around the Bab el Hadeed Station, and at a quarter-past eleven the crowd was considerable; but the approach- es were kept clear by mounted and foot police for those who had been honored with an invitation to meet his Highness on the arrival platform.

The station presented a very gay spectacle with its abundant display of the Ottoman flag and decorated shields, and the route along which his Highness passed as he drove to Abdeen Palace was plentiful decorated in a similar manner, but the varied colours of the many nations flags which hung from the larger buildings, afforded a welcome relief to the predominant red.

Shortly after eleven o’clock a guard of honor, composed of three officers and 100 non-commissioned offers and men of the 3rd Battalion, with the battalion colour and the Cavalry Band, was drawn up inside the station, while outside the station, in front of the main exit, the Army of Occupation provided a guard of honor, composed of one captain, three subalterns, and 100 rank and file of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, with the battalion colour and band. Punctually at half-past eleven the Khedividal train entered Cairo station and drew up at platform No. 2 Major L’Estrange John- sto, Capt. Blakeney, Mr. Bain, M. Barois, and Mr. Crossby ac compained the train from Alexandria, Mr. Crossby being in charge of the engine.

As his Highness stepped from the carriage the colour of the 3rd Battalion was dipped in salute and the Cavalry Band played the Khedivial anthem, while a salute of 21 guns was fired from the open space between Pont Limoun and Bab El Hadeed stations. Shaking hands with all those who had come to meet him, the Khedive gradually made his way to the main exit, and as he descended the steps he was saluted by the guard of honor of the 2nd R. Inniskilling Fusiliers and the playing of the Khedivial anthem by the battalion band, after which his Highness stepped into his carriage and, preceded by his Body Guard, drove through the crowded streets to Abdeen Palace.

Among those present en the railway plat- form we noticed H.E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, and the Ministers, who came up from Alex- andria with the Khedive, Sir Vincent Corbet, Mr. Machell, Mr. Webb, Mr. Dunlop, H.E. the Sirdar and officers of the Egyptian Army Brig. Gen. Bullock, C.B., and officers of the Army of Occupation. Ramadan Pasha, Baghcs Pasha Nubar, Sir Horace Pinching, Me. Carton de Wiart, Capt. Blakeney, Mr. Moberly, Mr. Fosden, Mr. Peacock, and many others.

div.head: DAIRA SANIEH LAWSUIT.
THE NEXT-OF-KIN OF THE KHEDIVE ISMAIL AND THE EGYPTIAN GOVERNMENT.
div.p: The following letter appears in the “Times” of the 18th inst. :-
Sir, I have read your notice of this matter in your issue of to-day, and ask you to permit me to make a comment on it on behalf of my clients, the next-of-kin.

The claimants do not “invoke such preced- ents as the seigneurial rights over landed property in Europe during the Middle Ages by virtue of conquest” in support of their claim, but to rebut Lord Cromer’s assertion tat the Daria Sanieh properties were first acquired by the Khedive Ismail in an illegal manner, considering as they do that this assertion is an aspersion upon their late father’s memory.

The point is, after all, a side issue, but it has this importance, that if the title of the Khedivial family be impugned the Egyptian Government, who can only derive their title through the Khedivial family (since confisca- tions are prohibited in the Ottoman Empire since the Hatti Cherif of Gull Hane (1839), confirmed by the Hatt Houmayoun of 1856, and extented to Egypt by the Firman of 1867 constituting the Egyptian Viceroyalty), impugn their own title

As a matter of fact the Daira Sanieh pro- perties, for the most part, descended to Ismail Pasha, as the grandson of Mehemet Ali, the conqueror of Egypt, before he came Viceroy, and neither the High Commission of Inquiry nor the Liquidation Commission (of both of which Lord Cromer was a member) ever made any inquiry into the first acquisition of the Daira Sanieh properties.

The real point at issue is that if the Egyptian Government have any title at all they must have derived it through Ismail Pasha, and that if there ever was any transfer or even any promise to transfer by him it was for a specific purpose only—namely, that the deficit which then existed might be wiped out. It is interesting in this particular to give Lord Cromer’s words uttered at the sitting of the High Commission of Inquiry of August 7, 1878, in extenso. They are as follows:- “Mr. Baring thought that the Commission should decide as follows.:-

1. The amount of the deficit is such a sum. 2. The Khedive is personally responsible for the present situation. 3. He has lands acquired in an irregular manner. 4. He should restore them to the State to an amount sufficient to meet the deficit.” The next-of-kin claim that, the deficit hav- ing been met, the surplus should revert to them.

May I, in conclusion, point out that the opinion expressed by the legal adviser your correspondent speaks of (really the Legal Department of the Egyptian Government) is not shared by the advisers to the next-of-kin. They take a diametrically opposite view, and including, as they do, the late Mr. Waldeck- Roussean, M. Poincare, and others, their opinion is equally entitled to weight.
I am, Sir, your obedient servant, H. ERNEST GARLE, Solicitor to the next- of-kin.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: At its meeting held yesterday forenoon under the presidency of H.E. Abdul-Hamid Pasha Sadik, the Legislative Council discussed the question of the Armenian Catholic Com- munity and approved the draft project for its recognition as a separate religious community, while suggesting a few modifications. The draft will shortly be submitted to the Council of Ministers.

div.head: THE NEW GRAND MUFTI OF EGYPT.
div.p: It is reported that Sheikh El-Rafey is about to be appointed Grand Mufti of Egypt in the place of the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdon. The Ministry of Justice proposed his appointment, to which no objections have been raised by H.H. the Khedive.
EGYPTIAN FINANCE

The monthly supplement to the “Official Journal” which gives the state of the Egypt- tian finances, shows that the revenue for the month of September amounted to L.E. 935,605 and the expenditure to L.E. 767,756. For the first nine months of the present year the revenue totalled L.E. 9,330,235, against L.E. 8,531,974 in the first three quar- ters of 1984. The total expenditure for the same period amounted to L.E. 8.215,511 in 1905,- against L.E. 7,366,510 in 1904. The increase of the revenue side of the 1905 as- count is most marked in the case of the State Railways, which show an increase of L.E. 1,156,684, against L.E. 1,111,164, an increase of L.E. 45, 520, the Telegraphs and Postal Administration taken together show an increase of receipts amounting to L.E. 18,651, and the revenues of the Port of Alexandria amount to L.E. 173,826, against L.E. 157,222 in the first nine months of 1904. On the side of expenditure, the most marked increase comes under the heading of the Railways and amounts to L.E. 236,706.

div.head: ARISTON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
ALEXANDRIA: 7 Rue de la Poste.
CAIRO opposite the Tramways Co. Works, Sharia Sahal, Kasr-el-Nil

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
ASSAULT ON ENGLISHMAN.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: Port Said, Wednesday.

On Monday evening, at about 10 o’clock, an Englishman, while walking between the Canal Company’s offices and those of Messrs Worms, was knocked down by three Greeks, after a short but sharp scuffle. The Englishman managed to draw a revolver which he carried, whereupon the three men immediately decamp- ed. No trace of them can be found and there have been no arrests.

div.head: NIGHT NAVIGATION IN CANAL.
div.p: The canal will be open to navigation at night on and after the 26th inst. The last date on which vessels passed kil. 18.4 after dark was September 4.

div.head: MOVEMENTS OF WARSHIPS
div.p: H.M.S Terrible left here at 4.10 this morning. She has proceeded to Suez for coaling and to be in readiness to accompany the Renown. When the Cambrian arrives she is expected to do likewise.

div.head: THE SIRDAR.
div.p: The date of H.E the Sirdar’s departure for the Sudan has been fixed for November 3. Lady Wingate, Miss Wingate, Miss Dansford, Miss Muirhead, Major and Mrs. Stack, Capt. Vaughan, and Mr. Collins will accompany his Excellency. A Government steam dahabieh will meet the party at Luxor, and they will proceed straight to Khartoum on the follow- ing day.

div.head: MR. MACHELL’S ENGAGEMENT.
div.p: The marriage between P.W. Machell and Countess Victoria Alice Leopoldine Ada Laura Gleichen, daughter of Princess Victor of Hohenlohe- Langenburg and the late Prince Victor, who died in 1891, will take place at the Chapel Royal, St. Jame’s Palace, on De- cember 5 next. The honeymoon will probably be spent at Wollaton Hall, Notts, the seat of Lord Middleton, the bridgeroom’s cousin.

Countess Victoria, who is perhaps better known to the world as Countess Valda, belongs to a talented family. She is an accomplished musician and is the possessor of a beautiful and highly-trained soprano-voice. Her only brother, Lieut.-Colonel Count Gleichen, who is at present military attache at Berlin, is a keen soldier and a successful author ; her eldest sister, Countess Feodora, has made name and fame as a sculptor, and her young- est sister paints very well, especially horses and cattle, and bids fair to follow in the foot- steps of Rosa Bonheur.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL INTERVIEWED.
div.p: In a conversation with a representative of the well-known French daily “La Libre Parole,” Mustapha Pasha Kamel stated that France had lost much by her agreement with England. French statesmen had promised to support Egypt but they had cancelled their valuable promises of support, and in consequence France had lost her influence in Egypt. The Anglo- French agreement, in which English states- manship shone, was a warning to the whole Orient not to trust in France. France had no friendly intentions toward two great Mohame- dan nations, Egypt and Morocco; but Morocco, which had long been independent, would not be easily subdued. Even if the Sultan of Morocco were to submit to French influence— which was most doubtful- his people would never submit. France should consider the consequences of her action.

div.head: COAL TRUCKS WANTED.
div.p: We understand that the great shortage of railway trucks for the transport of coal is causing considerable anxiety to coal merchants at Alexandria, who find trade suffering gravely from the want of wagons. The increase of the coal trade in the last few months has been very great, and has not been met by any increase in the quantity of the rolling stock We hope that the Railway Administration will be able to satisfy the demands of the Alexandria coal merchants as soon as possible.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The moss liner Ramses sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta, with pas- sengers, mails and general cargo, including 4,763 bales cotton.
The Ellerman S.S Sardinia sailed from Malta last evening and is due here on Satur- day evening with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

The S.S Royal Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left London on Tuesday and is due at Alexandria on or about Nov. 10. The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria at 6 a.m. yesterday.
The S.S. Orchia (Wescott & Laurance Line) left Malta yesterday and is due hers on Sunday with general cargo from Antwerp and London.

div.head: THE ROYAL TOUR
ARRIVAL OF H.M.S RENOWM
div.p: A telegram from our Port Said Correspondent, received as we are going to press, states that H.M.S. Renown, with T.B.H. the Prince and Princess of Wales on board, is due there at 3 p.m. to-day.

There is little likelihood that the Prince and Princess of Wales will go to Cairo on this occasion, but it is stated that their Royal Highnesses will visit Egypt on their way home from India next spring.

div.head: GIANT TOADS.
THE ZOO’S LATEST ADDITIONS.
div.p: Two giant toads have just arrived at the Ghizeh Zoological Gardens from South Ame- rica. They are more than four times the size of the ordinary toad or frog of this country, and have wonderfully beautiful eyes like glow- ing precious stones. Apparently, during their long voyage of several weeks from their native country they refused all food. On the first day of their arrival at Ghizeh they continued their self-imposed fast, but on the second day one of these enormous batrachians seized and swallowed three live young rats in the space of five minutes, and then settled down to a meal of earth-worms, which is expected to form their usual diet during their stay in Egypt.

The director of these gardens, Captain S.S. Flower, has just returned from Europe, after an absence of seven weeks, and has brought with him a number of new animals for the menagerie, mostly species of monkeys from West Africa, not represented previously in the collection.

div.head: SALE OF MENA HOUSE.
div.p: With regard to the Mena House Hotel sale, we hear that Mr. Emil Weckel, who had a twenty years’ lease of the hotel, of which only three years has elapsed, has sold his interests to Mrs. Locke-King, but on the understanding that he is to carry on the business for his own account until the 15th May, 1906, when he will hand it over to that lady, who will then transfer it to the George Nungovich Hotels Company. This agreement has been made notwithstanding the fact that the hotel becomes the property of the above company at an earlier date.
Mr. Weckel, at the end of the season, hopes to retire from business altogether and to settle down in Germany.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.H. Prince Abbas Pasha Halim, H.E. Fakhry Pasha, H.E. Boutros Pasha Ghali, and the Financial Adviser arrived here yesterday afternoon.
The Grand Cadi left yesterday for Constan- tinpole by the Khedivial mail steamer.
Sir R. von Slatin Pasha left Cairo for Luxor yesterday by the night train.

Among the large party who left by the same train we noticed Miralai Bond Bey, Miralai Stanton Bey, Mrs. Stanton and Miss Willis, Kaimaksm Roberts Bey, Bimbashi Airey, Bim- bashi Elderson, Major Gamble, Capt. Collins, Mr. Hewison, Miss Hewison, and Miss Bingley.

Miralai Az’z Bey, Turkish Consul at New York, has recently arrived in Cairo and is stay- ing at Shepheard’s Hotel. Aziz Bey acted as the Ottoman military attache in the South African war, where he accompanied Lord. Kit- chener’s staff.
H.M. the Sultan has conferred the rank of Salissa upon Gergis Bey Hawi, a well-known advocate of Zifta.
The marriage of Mlle Elise Brandt to Mr. Ettore Croccolo will take place on Saturday next.
